awd_titl_txt: Quantum electron solids and interaction-driven phenomena in two- and one-dimensional systems
awd_abstract_narration:
Nontechnical:  Electrons are tiny quantum mechanical objects that exist in all physical systems and most systems contain a large number of them. Understanding how electrons interact with each other and with the environment is a vital scientific subject and has played a critical role in advancing modern science and technologies. Analogous to water, electrons manifest both gaseous states at high temperatures and liquid states at low temperatures. Another form is a solid state which was predicted but never observed. To obtain evidence of this solid state of electrons is not only important in understanding how the most basic force can radically affect the quantum states, but also allows scientists to develop remarkable future quantum electronics and spintronics. These energy sustainable systems are fundamentally important to nature.  With greatly improved semiconductor technologies, a novel type of semiconductors of ultra-high purity has become available as a result of a recent breakthrough and preliminary results have been recently obtained as evidence of a genuine quantum electron solid. This project utilizes such devices to perform experiments with the most advanced scientific tools: nanofabrication and ultra-low temperature physics. The goal is to capture the direct evidence for the quantum mechanical mechanisms in the dynamical properties. This project supports the education of one Ph.D. student in pursuing discovery and advanced technologies, and allows the group to conduct outreach activities with local high schools. 

Technical:  Remarkable new quantum phenomena, such as the even-denominator Fractional Quantum Hall Effect and Topological Insulators, emerge in response to strong inter-particle Coulomb interaction.  However, the most prominent interaction-driven effect, Wigner crystallization of electrons, has not been well established. This fascinating quantum matter (with spin ordering) is not only paramount to fundamental science, but also important for future applications including quantum electronics and spintronics. For a long time, experimental effort was hindered because most devices contain a high level of unwanted disorder which overwhelms the interaction effect at low electron densities. Since 2003, breakthroughs have been made in providing ultra-high quality two-dimensional electron systems in GaAs semiconductor field-effect-transistors. Recent achievement with the measurement of ultrahigh purity GaAs field-effect transistors (named HIGFET) has led to the observation of a genuine WC. Moreover, the preliminary results also point to possible quantum pinning/depinning mechanisms that are not understood. This project utilizes these types of devices with record low electron densities to perform transport experiments at mK temperatures. The goal is to verify the quantum nature of the dynamical properties well below the classical limits. Various techniques such varying temperature, density, and interaction are adopted to study the phase boundaries.  AC+DC excitation technique is utilized to directly probe the collective, large-scale quantum tunneling in a Wigner Crystal.  This project supports the education of one Ph.D. student in pursuing discovery and in learning advanced technologies, which are indispensable for excellent training in pursuing scientific careers.

por.por_cntn:
This proposal was set out to discover electron phase transitions in the form of liquid-solid transition in two-dimensional systems where electrons are under dominating (Coulomb) interaction with each other and other competing effects such as those stemming from disorder are suppressed. Realization of electron systems with dominating interaction in the absence of an external magnetic field is very challenging because it must be realized in the limit of ultra-dilute charge concentrations where the system is vulnerable to disorder and temperature fluctuations because the energy scales of the system is exceedingly low. Therefore, in addition to the requirement of ultra-low system disorders, the measurement must be performed at tiny signal excitations and at very low temperatures down to 10 mK.

 

Because of these extreme experimental conditions, a significant amount of work on developing clean sample fabrication and state-of-the-art low temperature measurement techniques has been conducted and accomplished successfully. Sources of contamination or degradation that usually affect the sample quality have been effectively eliminated/suppressed. For low temperature cooling, we fabricated a special sample cell containing liquid helium-3 to successfully cool the sample to 10 mK. We also fabricated porous sintered silver structures to achieve excellent filtering of electrical noises and vibrational noises. We also built electronics suitable for sourcing and sensing at ultra-high resolutions. Below is a summary of the experimental results that have proven for the first time a quantum phase transition and behaviors supporting a genuine electron solid (Wigner crystal) phase.

1. By tuning interaction beyond a certain threshold, we observed a phase transition. This transition is signified by a benchmark critical behavior in a characteristic energy which diminish abruptly at the critical point. The value of the critical point is in a remakable agreement with the theoretical prediction. These results along with the nonactivated transport unambiguously identify the interaction-driven nature of the phase transition.

2. By driving the system into the Wigner crystal regime, a temperature dependence measurement of the system differential resistance produces both the key features of a Wigner crystal phase and the signatures of an unusual phase transition.  In contrast to the common belief, there are two critical temperatures, Tc1 and Tc2, observed. Below Tc1, the system is strongly pinned by residual disorders marked by an enormous differential resistance. A sharp discontinuity is observed when rasing the temperature across Tc1 and the pinning strength plummets by 95%. The discontinuity, which is never observed before, is a hard evidence of a first-order phase transition. At Tc2, pinning diminishes completely due to the forming of an isotropic liquid. Therefore, for temperatures between Tc1 and Tc2, the system enters an intermediate phase. Thus, this unusual phase transition process confirms that a complex phase diagram in the quantum limit.

3. By alternating the signal drives at temperatures below Tc1, we observed that the system undergoes a phase transition by simply increasing the drives beyond a certain threshold. Because the signal drive effectively produces the potential energy of the pinned charges, increasing the signal levels is equivalent to raising the pressure which results a pressure-driven phase transition above a threshold. 

4. The presence of the intermediate phase provides a new perspectives on whether a Wigner crystal slides like the charge density waves. Because of the lower energy scales of the intermediate phase compared to a sliding crystal which requires much more energy to overcome the gap, it is more beneficial for the system to enter the intermediate phase that has much less pinning effect.

5. Our results help clarify a long-standing puzzling effect related to the collective states under weak pinning which was extensively observed by previous studies. This is because those systems were actually in an intermediate or a glass phase instead of a Wigner crystal.

6. The interaction-driven phase transition and the novel intermediate phase could potentially open up new frontiers when combining with current studies related to topology and magnetism important to developing next generation quantum computation and information technologies.

Modified by: Jian Huang
